Line 47: Line 47:  
:'''''An event that receives coverage in a wide variety of sources is likely to be notable.'''''
 
:'''''An event that receives coverage in a wide variety of sources is likely to be notable.'''''
    −
Per [[WP:GNG|Wikipedia's general notability guideline]], ''multiple sources'' are required, not just multiple references from a single source. A series of news reports by a single newspaper or news channel would not be sufficient basis for an article.
+
[[WP:GNG|Wikipedia's general notability guideline]] recommends that multiple sources be provided to establish the notability of a topic, not just multiple references from a single source.<ref>From [[WP:GNG]]: "Lack of multiple sources suggests that the topic may be more suitable for inclusion in an article on a broader topic. Mere republications of a single source or news wire service do not always constitute multiple works. Several journals simultaneously publishing articles in the same geographic region about an occurrence, does not always constitute multiple works, especially when the authors are relying on the same sources, and merely restating the same information. Specifically, several journals publishing the same article within the same geographic region from a news wire service is not a multiplicity of works."</ref> A series of news reports by a single newspaper or news channel would not be sufficient basis for an article.
     
Similarly, where a single news wire story or press release has been used (often word-for-word) by several news publications, this should only be counted as a single source for the purpose of determining notability (see [[Wikipedia:Bombardment]]). Likewise, when reporters base their information on other news coverage (for example, "[[Associated Press|AP]] reported that ..."), the coverage is only a single source. Such derivative reports are not independent of each other and so cannot be used to verify each other. However, if multiple mainstream news outlets report on a single event separately and without being substantially based upon others, these constitute multiple sources.

Such derivative reports are not independent of each other and so cannot be used to verify each other. However, if multiple mainstream news outlets report on a single event separately and without being substantially based upon others, these constitute multiple sources.

Line 22: Line 22:  
:'''''An event must receive significant or in-depth coverage to be notable.'''''
 
:'''''An event must receive significant or in-depth coverage to be notable.'''''
    −
The general guideline is that coverage must be significant and not in passing. In depth coverage includes analysis that puts events into context, such as is often found in books, feature length articles in major news magazines (like ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'', ''[[Newsweek]]'', and ''[[The Economist]]''), and TV news specialty shows (such as ''[[60 Minutes]]'' or ''[[CNN Presents]]''). Reporting with little thematic connection or contextual information,<ref>http://www.questia.com/googleScholar.qst;jsessionid=KjpQbmrL6PGhG9rrVG2Gg1NWkb8PJQ8stDyWpNlfWvvP7vv2X7C1!1977393224!-1845046985?docId=5002028519</ref> or lacking insight or critique,<ref>http://books.google.co.uk/books?hl=en&lr=&id=JV0XQUF-o6gC&oi=fnd&pg=PA230&dq=%22Routine+news+coverage%22&ots=D24lsTZgV8&sig=7GIp4N5-wEMNSWgKYYFbDGn0prI#v=onepage&q=%22Routine%20news%20coverage%22&f=false</ref><ref>http://books.google.co.uk/books?hl=en&lr=&id=M7L1d_XjwsoC&oi=fnd&pg=PA61&dq=Routine#v=onepage&q=Routine&f=false</ref> is often considered to be routine reporting. Some editors consider narrative news reports to be [[WP:PRIMARY|primary]] rather than secondary sources.

Wikipedia is [[Wikipedia:What Wikipedia is not#Wikipedia is not a paper encyclopedia|not a paper encyclopedia]], which means that there is no practical limit to the number of topics we can cover or the total amount of content. The general guideline is that coverage must be significant and not in passing. In depth coverage includes analysis that puts events into context, such as is often found in books, feature length articles in major news magazines (like ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'', ''[[Newsweek]]'', and ''[[The Economist]]''), and TV news specialty shows (such as ''[[60 Minutes]]'' or ''[[CNN Presents]]''). Reporting with little thematic connection or contextual information,<ref>http://www.questia.com/googleScholar.qst;jsessionid=KjpQbmrL6PGhG9rrVG2Gg1NWkb8PJQ8stDyWpNlfWvvP7vv2X7C1!1977393224!-1845046985?docId=5002028519</ref> or lacking insight or critique,<ref>http://books.google.co.uk/books?hl=en&lr=&id=JV0XQUF-o6gC&oi=fnd&pg=PA230&dq=%22Routine+news+coverage%22&ots=D24lsTZgV8&sig=7GIp4N5-wEMNSWgKYYFbDGn0prI#v=onepage&q=%22Routine%20news%20coverage%22&f=false</ref><ref>http://books.google.co.uk/books?hl=en&lr=&id=M7L1d_XjwsoC&oi=fnd&pg=PA61&dq=Routine#v=onepage&q=Routine&f=false</ref> is often considered to be routine reporting. Some editors consider narrative news reports to be [[WP:PRIMARY|primary]] rather than secondary sources.

The duration of coverage is a strong indicator of whether an event has passing or lasting significance. Although [[WP:NTEMP|notability is not temporary]], meaning that coverage does not need to be ongoing for notability to be established, a burst or spike of news reports does not automatically make an incident notable. Events that are only covered in sources published during or immediately after an event, without further analysis or discussion, are likely not suitable for an encyclopedia article. However, this may be difficult or impossible to determine shortly after the event occurs, as editors [[WP:CRYSTAL|cannot know]] whether an event will receive further coverage or not. That an event occurred recently does not in itself make it non-notable.

'''Wikipedia:Notability (events)''' is a proposed<!-- remove "proposed" if this achieves consensus --> guideline intended to explicate the [[Wikipedia:Notability|primary notability guideline]] with regards to current and past real [[wiktionary:event|events]], as well as breaking news.
 
'''Wikipedia:Notability (events)''' is a proposed<!-- remove "proposed" if this achieves consensus --> guideline intended to explicate the [[Wikipedia:Notability|primary notability guideline]] with regards to current and past real [[wiktionary:event|events]], as well as breaking news.
      +
==Background==
−
Whether Wikipedia should have articles detailing particular events or incidents is a perennial and contentious question. Generally, a topic is presumed to be [[WP:NOTABILITY|notable]] and thus worthy of inclusion within Wikipedia if it has received significant coverage in multiple, independent [[WP:RS|reliable sources]]. This is the [[WP:GNG|general notability guideline]].
        +
[[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion]] has featured a number of contentious debates about events, particularly breaking news events, that have received intense media coverage.<!-- consider adding examples here, similar to the format of the introduction to [[Wikipedia:Notability (criminal acts)]] --> Several [[Wikipedia:Policies and guidelines|policies and guidelines within Wikipedia]] stand out as being frequently cited in these debates. Recommendations for "keep" often cite the breadth of coverage as satisfying the [[WP:GNG|general notability guideline]] which states that "a topic is presumed to have met the criteria for notability if it has received significant coverage in [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources|reliable sources]] that are [[Wikipedia:Independent sources|independent]] of the subject." Recommendations for "delete" often cite [[WP:NOT#NEWS]], a sub-section of [[Wikipedia:What Wikipedia is not]] that refers to new reports, as well as [[WP:BLP1E]] and [[WP:BIO1E]] which refer to the notability of people known for their role in a single event. Other guidelines often cited in Afd debates include [[WP:NTEMP]] and [[WP:N/CA]]. By attempting to clarify the application of these rules to articles about events, this guideline is proposed as an attempt to develop a [[Wikipedia:Consensus|community consensus]] on how future similarly situated articles should be handled.
⚫
Wikipedia is [[Wikipedia:What Wikipedia is not#Wikipedia is not a paper encyclopedia|not a paper encyclopedia]], which means that there is no practical limit to the number of topics we can cover or the total amount of content. However, it is also [[WP:NOT#IINFO|not an indiscriminate collection of information]] or a [[Wikipedia:NOT#NEWS|news service]]. [[Wikinews]] offers a place where editors can document a current [[news]] event, but not every incident that gains media coverage will have or should have a Wikipedia article. Reporting should be in sources that have a national or global scope, and a rule of thumb on whether an article should be written is whether the event is of lasting, historical significance, bearing in mind the question of [[Wikipedia:Recentism|recentism]].

Line 70: Line 70:  
It is wise to delay writing an article about a breaking news event until the significance of the event is clearer as early coverage may lack perspective and be subject to factual errors. Writing about breaking news may be [[WP:RECENTISM|recentism]], and [[WP:CRYSTAL|Wikipedia is not a crystal ball]]. It is recommended that editors start a section about the event within an article on a related topic, which may later be split into its own article if the coverage suggests that the event is independently notable.

Writing about breaking news may be [[WP:RECENTISM|recentism]], and [[WP:CRYSTAL|Wikipedia is not a crystal ball]]. It is recommended that editors start a section about the event within an article on a related topic, which may later be split into its own article if the coverage suggests that the event is independently notable.
    −
Many articles on events are created in ''anticipation'' of their notability. Anticipation is the creation of an article on a recent event with the expectation that it will meet inclusion guidelines, before the persistence of coverage or any lasting effect is certain. For example, [[2009 Washington Metro train collision]] was started just 60 minutes after the crash occurred. The rescue operation was still ongoing, an investigation was yet to begin, and the final death toll was unknown.
+
Many articles on events are created in ''anticipation'' of their notability. Anticipation is the creation of an article on a recent event with the expectation that it will meet inclusion guidelines, before the duration of coverage or any lasting effect is certain. For example, [[2009 Washington Metro train collision]] was started just 60 minutes after the crash occurred. The rescue operation was still ongoing, an investigation was yet to begin, and the final death toll was unknown.
     
Anticipation of notability may be mistaken. Many events portrayed by the media as major on the day they occur quickly become only a footnote. For example, it was reported in January 2009 that [[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/Asa Seeley|a man was planning to travel to Washington to assassinate George W. Bush]]. It was reported several days later that he had no such plans and this event was shown to be nothing more than a [[West Baltimore (MARC station)#Site of arrest|routine arrest]]. However, articles about widely reported major unexpected or unprecedented events such as the [[2004 Indian Ocean earthquake]], the [[Assassination of Benazir Bhutto]] or the [[Death of Michael Jackson]] will almost certainly gain consensus to be kept even when created on the same day as the event occurred.

However, articles about widely reported major unexpected or unprecedented events such as the [[2004 Indian Ocean earthquake]], the [[Assassination of Benazir Bhutto]] or the [[Death of Michael Jackson]] will almost certainly gain consensus to be kept even when created on the same day as the event occurred.

Line 48: Line 48:  
Similarly, where a single news wire story or press release has been used (often word-for-word) by several news publications, this should only be counted as a single source for the purpose of determining notability (see [[Wikipedia:Bombardment]]). Likewise, when reporters base their information on other news coverage (for example, "[[Associated Press|AP]] reported that ..."), the coverage is only a single source. Such derivative reports are not independent of each other and so cannot be used to verify each other. However, if multiple mainstream news outlets report on a single event separately and without being substantially based upon others, these constitute multiple sources.

'''Wikipedia:Notability (events)''' is a proposed<!-- remove "proposed" if this achieves consensus --> guideline intended to explicate the [[Wikipedia:Notability|primary notability guideline]] with regards to current and past real events, as well as breaking news.
     
Whether Wikipedia should have articles detailing particular [[wiktionary:event|events]] or incidents is a perennial and contentious question. Generally, a topic is presumed to be [[WP:NOTABILITY|notable]] and thus worthy of inclusion within Wikipedia if it has received significant coverage in multiple, independent [[WP:RS|reliable sources]]. This is the [[WP:GNG|general notability guideline]].

Line 59: Line 59:  
==Routine coverage==
 
==Routine coverage==
 
{{shortcut|WP:ROUTINE}}
 
{{shortcut|WP:ROUTINE}}
−        
[[WP:NOTNEWS|Per Wikipedia policy]], routine news coverage of such things as announcements, sports, and tabloid journalism are not sufficient basis for an article. Planned coverage of pre-scheduled events,<ref>http://english.peopledaily.com.cn/english/200102/08/eng20010208_61814.html</ref><ref>http://mcs.sagepub.com/cgi/content/abstract/20/3/471</ref> especially when those involved in the event are also promoting it,<ref>http://books.google.co.uk/books?hl=en&lr=&id=JV0XQUF-o6gC&oi=fnd&pg=PA200&dq=Routine#v=onepage&q=Routine&f=false</ref> is considered to be routine. Wedding announcements, obituaries, sports scores, crime logs, and other items that tend to get an exemption from newsworthiness discussions should be considered routine. Routine events such as sports matches, film premieres, press conferences etc. may be better covered as part of another article, if at all. [[Wikipedia:Run-of-the-mill|Run-of-the-mill]] events — common, everyday, ordinary items that do not stand out — are probably not notable. This is especially true of the brief, often light and amusing (for example bear-in-a-tree or local-person-wins-award), stories that frequently appear in the back pages of newspapers or near the end of nightly news broadcasts ([[wiktionary:and finally|"And finally"]] stories).

Routine events such as sports matches, film premieres, press conferences etc. may be better covered as part of another article, if at all. [[Wikipedia:Run-of-the-mill|Run-of-the-mill]] events — common, everyday, ordinary items that do not stand out — are probably not notable. This is especially true of the brief, often light and amusing (for example bear-in-a-tree or local-person-wins-award), stories that frequently appear in the back pages of newspapers or near the end of nightly news broadcasts ([[wiktionary:and finally|"And finally"]] stories).

Line 74: Line 74:  
Anticipation of notability may be mistaken. Many events portrayed by the media as major on the day they occur quickly become only a footnote. For example, it was reported in January 2009 that [[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/Asa Seeley|a man was planning to travel to Washington to assassinate George W. Bush]]. It was reported several days later that he had no such plans and this event was shown to be nothing more than a [[West Baltimore (MARC station)#Site of arrest|routine arrest]]. However, articles about widely reported major unexpected or unprecedented events such as the [[2004 Indian Ocean earthquake]], the [[Assassination of Benazir Bhutto]] or the [[Death of Michael Jackson]] will almost certainly gain consensus to be kept even when created on the same day as the event occurred.
 
Anticipation of notability may be mistaken. Many events portrayed by the media as major on the day they occur quickly become only a footnote. For example, it was reported in January 2009 that [[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/Asa Seeley|a man was planning to travel to Washington to assassinate George W. Bush]]. It was reported several days later that he had no such plans and this event was shown to be nothing more than a [[West Baltimore (MARC station)#Site of arrest|routine arrest]]. However, articles about widely reported major unexpected or unprecedented events such as the [[2004 Indian Ocean earthquake]], the [[Assassination of Benazir Bhutto]] or the [[Death of Michael Jackson]] will almost certainly gain consensus to be kept even when created on the same day as the event occurred.
    −
Articles about breaking news events —particularly biographies of participants— are often rapidly nominated for deletion. As [[WP:DEADLINE|there is no deadline]], it is recommended to delay the nomination for a few days to avoid the deletion debate dealing with a moving target and to allow time for a clearer picture of the notability of the event to emerge. There may be alternatives to deletion such as merging or reworking the article so that it conforms with policy, such as rewriting an article about a person known only for one event to be about the event. Other alternatives to deletion while the story develops are [[WP:USERFY|userfying]] or moving the article into the [[WP:INCUBATE|Article Incubator]].
+
Articles about breaking news events —particularly biographies of participants— are often rapidly nominated for deletion. As [[WP:DEADLINE|there is no deadline]], it is recommended to delay the nomination for a few days to avoid the deletion debate dealing with a moving target and to allow time for a clearer picture of the notability of the event to emerge, which may make a deletion nomination unnecessary. There may be alternatives to deletion such as merging or reworking the article so that it conforms with policy, such as rewriting an article about a person known only for one event to be about the event. Other alternatives to deletion while the story develops are [[WP:USERFY|userfying]] or moving the article into the [[WP:INCUBATE|Article Incubator]].

There is a category, [[:Category:Events]], which may be a guide to the kind of articles about events considered acceptable by the community.
 
Editors should evaluate various aspects of the coverage: the depth, persistence, geographical scope, diversity and reliability of the coverage, as well whether the coverage is routine and the impact of the event. There is a category, [[:Category:Events]], which may be a guide to the kind of articles about events considered acceptable by the community.
    −
In general, a news event must meet the following criteria to qualify for inclusion in a Wikipedia article:
+
In general, a news event must meet all of the following criteria to qualify for an independent Wikipedia article:
     
===Depth of coverage===
 
===Depth of coverage===
−
*'''''An event that receives significant or in-depth coverage is likely to be notable.'''''
  −    
The general guideline is that coverage must be significant and not in passing. In depth coverage includes analysis that puts events into context, such as is often found in books, feature length articles in major news magazines (like ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'', ''[[Newsweek]]'', and ''[[The Economist]]''), and TV news specialty shows (such as ''[[60 Minutes]]'' or ''[[CNN Presents]]''). Reporting with little thematic connection or contextual information,<ref>http://www.questia.com/googleScholar.qst;jsessionid=KjpQbmrL6PGhG9rrVG2Gg1NWkb8PJQ8stDyWpNlfWvvP7vv2X7C1!1977393224!-1845046985?docId=5002028519</ref> or lacking insight or critique,<ref>http://books.google.co.uk/books?hl=en&lr=&id=JV0XQUF-o6gC&oi=fnd&pg=PA230&dq=%22Routine+news+coverage%22&ots=D24lsTZgV8&sig=7GIp4N5-wEMNSWgKYYFbDGn0prI#v=onepage&q=%22Routine%20news%20coverage%22&f=false</ref><ref>http://books.google.co.uk/books?hl=en&lr=&id=M7L1d_XjwsoC&oi=fnd&pg=PA61&dq=Routine#v=onepage&q=Routine&f=false</ref> is often considered to be routine reporting. Some editors consider narrative news reports to be [[WP:PRIMARY|primary]] rather than secondary sources.

    Line 27: Line 25:      
===Persistence of coverage===
 
===Persistence of coverage===
−
{{shortcut|WP:CONTINUEDCOVERAGE}}
+
{{shortcut|WP:CONTINUEDCOVERAGE|WP:PERSISTENCE}}
−
*'''''An event that receives persistent or on-going coverage is likely to be notable.'''''
       
The persistence or duration of coverage is a strong indicator of whether an event has passing or lasting significance. Although [[WP:NTEMP|notability is not temporary]], meaning that coverage does not need to be ongoing for notability to be established, a burst or spike of news reports does not automatically make an incident notable. Editors [[WP:CRYSTAL|should not speculate]] on whether an event will receive further coverage. Events that are only covered in sources published during or immediately after an event, without further analysis or discussion, are likely not suitable for an encyclopedia article.

    Line 51: Line 47:  
Similarly, where a single news wire story or press release has been used (often word-for-word) by several news publications, this should only be counted as a single source for the purpose of determining notability (see [[Wikipedia:Bombardment]]). Likewise, when reporters base their information on other news coverage (for example, "[[Associated Press|AP]] reported that ..."), the coverage is only a single source. Such derivative reports are not independent of each other and so cannot be used to verify each other. However, if multiple mainstream news outlets report on a single event separately and without being substantially based upon others, these constitute multiple sources.

Some editors consider narrative news reports to be [[WP:PRIMARY|primary]] rather than secondary sources.
     
Media sources sometimes report on events because of their similarity to another widely reported incident. Editors should not rely on such sources to afford notability to the new event, since the main purpose of such articles is to highlight the old event.

    Line 26: Line 28:  
===Persistence of coverage===
 
===Persistence of coverage===
 
{{shortcut|WP:CONTINUEDCOVERAGE}}
 
{{shortcut|WP:CONTINUEDCOVERAGE}}
  +
*'''''An event that receives persistent or on-going coverage is likely to be notable.'''''
  +  
The persistence or duration of coverage is a strong indicator of whether an event has passing or lasting significance. Although [[WP:NTEMP|notability is not temporary]], meaning that coverage does not need to be ongoing for notability to be established, a burst or spike of news reports does not automatically make an incident notable. Editors [[WP:CRYSTAL|should not speculate]] on whether an event will receive further coverage. Events that are only covered in sources published during or immediately after an event, without further analysis or discussion, are likely not suitable for an encyclopedia article.

      ⚫

An event affecting a local area and reported only by the media within the immediate region is generally not notable as it is only of [[WP:LOCAL|local interest]]. Such coverage does not justify a separate article regardless of the number of [[WP:RS|reliable sources]] that can be provided. Coverage of an event nationally or internationally is generally required for inclusion, though it does ''not'' grant automatic notability to the event.

Line 47: Line 53:  
===Lasting effects===
 
===Lasting effects===
 
{{shortcut|WP:EFFECT}}
 
{{shortcut|WP:EFFECT}}
  +
*'''''An event that is a precedent or catalyst for something else of significance is likely to be notable.'''''
  +  
Events are often considered to be notable if they act as a precedent or catalyst for something else. This may include effects on the views and behaviors of society and legislation. For example, the [[Murder of Adam Walsh]] ultimately led to the [[Adam Walsh Child Protection and Safety Act]], among other notable subjects. The murder of [[Matthew Shepard]] has led to reform of [[hate crime]] legislation at local, state and federal levels, such as the [[Matthew Shepard Act]].

[[WP:NOTNEWS|Per Wikipedia policy]], routine news coverage of such things as announcements, sports, and tabloid journalism are not sufficient basis for an article. Wedding announcements, obituaries, sports scores, crime logs, and other items that tend to get an exemption from newsworthiness discussions should be considered routine. Routine events such as sports matches, film premieres, press conferences etc. may be better covered as part of another article, if at all. [[Wikipedia:Run-of-the-mill|Run-of-the-mill]] events — common, everyday, ordinary items that do not stand out — are probably not notable. Line 40: Line 42:      
Similarly, where a single news wire story or press release has been used (often word-for-word) by several news publications, this should only be counted as a single source for the purpose of determining notability (see [[Wikipedia:Bombardment]]). Likewise, when reporters base their information on other news coverage (for example, "[[Associated Press|AP]] reported that ..."), the coverage is only a single source. Such derivative reports are not independent of each other and so cannot be used to verify each other. However, if multiple mainstream news outlets report on a single event separately and without being substantially based upon others, these constitute multiple sources.

[[Tabloid_journalism#To_refer_to_sensationalist_journalistic_practices|Tabloid]] or [[yellow journalism]] is usually considered a poor basis for an encyclopedia article, due to the lack of fact checking inherent in [[Sensationalism|sensationalist]] and [[scandal mongering]] news reporting. Per policy, Wikipedia is not for scandal mongering or gossip. Even in respected media, a [[24-hour news cycle]] and other pressures inherent in the journalism industry can lead to [[infotainment]] and [[churnalism]] without proper fact checking, and they may engage in frivolous "[[silly season]]" reporting. Some editors take into account perceived [[media bias]], such as [[Missing white woman syndrome]], when assessing notability.

Line 92: Line 86:  
{{mainarticle|Wikipedia:Notability (criminal acts)}}
 
{{mainarticle|Wikipedia:Notability (criminal acts)}}
 
There is a specific notability guideline for criminal acts. A "criminal act" includes a matter in which a crime has been established, or a matter has been deemed a likely crime by the relevant law enforcement agency or judicial authority. For example, the disappearance of a person would fall under this guideline if law enforcement agencies deemed it likely to have been caused by criminal conduct, regardless of whether a perpetrator is identified or charged. If a matter is deemed notable, and to be a likely crime, the article should remain even if it is subsequently found that no crime occurred (e.g., the [[Runaway bride case]]) since that would not make the matter less notable. Intense media coverage can confer notability on a high-profile criminal act, provided such coverage meets Wikipedia's policies and guidelines on [[WP:RS|reliable sources]].

==Inclusion guidelines==

==Inclusion criteria==
 
Many events receive coverage in the news and yet are not of historic or lasting importance. News organizations have criteria for content, i.e. [[news values]], that differ from the criteria used by Wikipedia. A violent crime, accidental death, or other [[media event]]s may be interesting enough to reporters and news editors to justify coverage, but this will not always translate into sufficient notability for a Wikipedia article.

Line 69: Line 69:  
Many articles on events are created in ''anticipation'' of their notability. Anticipation is the creation of an article on a recent event with the expectation that it will meet inclusion guidelines, before the persistence of coverage or any lasting effect is certain. For example, [[2009 Washington Metro train collision]] was started just 60 minutes after the crash occurred. The rescue operation was still ongoing, an investigation was yet to begin, and the final death toll was unknown.
 
Many articles on events are created in ''anticipation'' of their notability. Anticipation is the creation of an article on a recent event with the expectation that it will meet inclusion guidelines, before the persistence of coverage or any lasting effect is certain. For example, [[2009 Washington Metro train collision]] was started just 60 minutes after the crash occurred. The rescue operation was still ongoing, an investigation was yet to begin, and the final death toll was unknown.
    −
Anticipation of notability will often be mistaken. Many events portrayed by the media as major on the day they occur quickly become only a footnote. For example, it was reported in January 2009 that [[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/Asa Seeley|a man was planning to travel to Washington to assassinate George W. Bush]]. It was reported several days later that he had no such plans and this event was shown to be nothing more than a [[West Baltimore (MARC station)#Site of arrest|routine arrest]]. However, articles about widely reported major unexpected or unprecedented events such as the [[2004 Indian Ocean earthquake]], the [[Assassination of Benazir Bhutto]] or the [[Death of Michael Jackson]] will almost certainly gain consensus to be kept even when created on the same day as the event occurred.
+
Anticipation of notability may be mistaken. Many events portrayed by the media as major on the day they occur quickly become only a footnote. For example, it was reported in January 2009 that [[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/Asa Seeley|a man was planning to travel to Washington to assassinate George W. Bush]]. It was reported several days later that he had no such plans and this event was shown to be nothing more than a [[West Baltimore (MARC station)#Site of arrest|routine arrest]]. However, articles about widely reported major unexpected or unprecedented events such as the [[2004 Indian Ocean earthquake]], the [[Assassination of Benazir Bhutto]] or the [[Death of Michael Jackson]] will almost certainly gain consensus to be kept even when created on the same day as the event occurred.
    −
Articles about breaking news events —particularly biographies of participants— are often rapidly nominated for deletion. Consider delaying the nomination for a few days to avoid the deletion debate dealing with a moving target. There may be alternatives to deletion such as merging or reworking the article so that it conforms with policy, such as rewriting an article about a person known only for one event to be about the event. Other alternatives to deletion while the story develops are [[WP:USERFY|userfying]] or moving the article into the [[WP:INCUBATE|Article Incubator]].
+
Articles about breaking news events —particularly biographies of participants— are often rapidly nominated for deletion. As [[WP:DEADLINE|there is no deadline]], it is recommended to delay the nomination for a few days to avoid the deletion debate dealing with a moving target and to allow time for a clearer picture of the notability of the event to emerge. There may be alternatives to deletion such as merging or reworking the article so that it conforms with policy, such as rewriting an article about a person known only for one event to be about the event. Other alternatives to deletion while the story develops are [[WP:USERFY|userfying]] or moving the article into the [[WP:INCUBATE|Article Incubator]].

Line 21: Line 21:      
===Persistence of coverage===
 
===Persistence of coverage===
  +
{{shortcut|WP:CONTINUEDCOVERAGE}}
 
The persistence or duration of coverage is a strong indicator of whether an event has passing or lasting significance. Although [[WP:NTEMP|notability is not temporary]], meaning that coverage does not need to be ongoing for notability to be established, a burst or spike of news reports does not automatically make an incident notable. Editors [[WP:CRYSTAL|should not speculate]] on whether an event will receive further coverage. Events that are only covered in sources published during or immediately after an event, without further analysis or discussion, are likely not suitable for an encyclopedia article.

Although [[WP:NTEMP|notability is not temporary]], meaning that coverage does not need to be ongoing for notability to be established, a burst or spike of news reports does not automatically make an incident notable. Editors [[WP:CRYSTAL|should not speculate]] on whether an event will receive further coverage. Events that are only covered in sources published during or immediately after an event, without further analysis or discussion, are likely not suitable for an encyclopedia article.

Policies and guidelines that editors often use as a guide on whether to have an article about a single event include [[WP:NOT#NEWS]], [[WP:NTEMP]], [[WP:BIO1E]], [[WP:BLP1E]], and [[WP:N/CA]]. This guideline clarifies the application of these rules to articles about events.

There is a category, [[:Category:Events]], which may be a guide to the kind of articles about events considered acceptable by the community.
 
Editors should evaluate various aspects of the coverage: the depth, persistence, geographical scope, diversity and reliability of the coverage, as well whether the coverage is routine and the impact of the event. There is a category, [[:Category:Events]], which may be a guide to the kind of articles about events considered acceptable by the community.

Line 81: Line 81:  
If an event is still being widely covered in the press, editors may place the <nowiki>{{currentevent}}</nowiki> template on it to inform readers of the changing nature of the article.
 
If an event is still being widely covered in the press, editors may place the <nowiki>{{currentevent}}</nowiki> template on it to inform readers of the changing nature of the article.
      ⚫
It is wise to delay writing an article about a breaking news event until the significance of the event is clearer as early coverage may lack perspective and be subject to factual errors. Writing about breaking news may be [[WP:RECENTISM|recentism]], and [[WP:CRYSTAL|Wikipedia is not a crystal ball]]. It is recommended that editors start a section about the event within an article on a related topic, which may later be split into its own article if the coverage suggests that the event is independently notable.
⚫
Many articles on events are created in ''anticipation'' of their notability. Anticipation is the creation of an article on a recent event with the expectation that it will meet inclusion guidelines, before the persistence of coverage or any lasting effect is certain. For example, [[2009 Washington Metro train collision]] was started just 60 minutes after the crash occurred. The rescue operation was still ongoing, an investigation was yet to begin, and the final death toll was unknown.

      −
Many events portrayed by the media as major on the day they occur quickly become only a footnote. For example, it was reported in January 2009 that [[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/Asa Seeley|a man was planning to travel to Washington to assassinate George W. Bush]]. It was reported several days later that he had no such plans and this event was shown to be nothing more than a [[West Baltimore (MARC station)#Site of arrest|routine arrest]].
+
Anticipation of notability will often be mistaken. Many events portrayed by the media as major on the day they occur quickly become only a footnote. For example, it was reported in January 2009 that [[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/Asa Seeley|a man was planning to travel to Washington to assassinate George W. Bush]]. It was reported several days later that he had no such plans and this event was shown to be nothing more than a [[West Baltimore (MARC station)#Site of arrest|routine arrest]]. However, articles about widely reported major unexpected or unprecedented events such as the [[2004 Indian Ocean earthquake]], the [[Assassination of Benazir Bhutto]] or the [[Death of Michael Jackson]] will almost certainly gain consensus to be kept even when created on the same day as the event occurred.
     
Articles about breaking news events —particularly biographies of participants— are often rapidly nominated for deletion. Consider delaying the nomination for a few days to avoid the deletion debate dealing with a moving target. There may be alternatives to deletion such as merging or reworking the article so that it conforms with policy, such as rewriting an article about a person known only for one event to be about the event. Other alternatives to deletion while the story develops are [[WP:USERFY|userfying]] or moving the article into the [[WP:INCUBATE|Article Incubator]].

Other alternatives to deletion while the story develops are [[WP:USERFY|userfying]] or moving the article into the [[WP:INCUBATE|Article Incubator]].

+
Per [[WP:GNG|Wikipedia's general notability guideline]], ''multiple sources'' are required, not just multiple references from a single source. A series of news reports by a single newspaper or news channel would not be sufficient basis for an article.
    −
Similarly, where a single news wire story or press release has been used (often word-for-word) by several news publications, this should only be counted as a single source in all notability decisions (see [[Wikipedia: Bombardment]]). Likewise, when reporters base their information on other news coverage (for example, "[[Associated Press|AP]] reported that ..."), the coverage is only a single source. Such derivative reports are not independent and so cannot be used to verify each other. However, if multiple mainstream news outlets report on a single event separately and without reference to others, these constitute multiple sources.
+
Similarly, where a single news wire story or press release has been used (often word-for-word) by several news publications, this should only be counted as a single source for the purpose of determining notability (see [[Wikipedia:Bombardment]]). Likewise, when reporters base their information on other news coverage (for example, "[[Associated Press|AP]] reported that ..."), the coverage is only a single source. Such derivative reports are not independent of each other and so cannot be used to verify each other. However, if multiple mainstream news outlets report on a single event separately and without being substantially based upon others, these constitute multiple sources.

Line 73: Line 73:  
Events are often considered to be notable if they act as a precedent or catalyst for something else. This may include effects on the views and behaviors of society and legislation. For example, the [[Murder of Adam Walsh]] ultimately led to the [[Adam Walsh Child Protection and Safety Act]], among other notable subjects. The murder of [[Matthew Shepard]] has led to reform of [[hate crime]] legislation at local, state and federal levels, such as the [[Matthew Shepard Act]].
 
Events are often considered to be notable if they act as a precedent or catalyst for something else. This may include effects on the views and behaviors of society and legislation. For example, the [[Murder of Adam Walsh]] ultimately led to the [[Adam Walsh Child Protection and Safety Act]], among other notable subjects. The murder of [[Matthew Shepard]] has led to reform of [[hate crime]] legislation at local, state and federal levels, such as the [[Matthew Shepard Act]].
    −
Events that have a noted and sourced permanent affect are notable. This includes, for example, natural disasters that result in widespread destruction, since they lead to rebuilding, population shifts, and possible impact on elections. For example, [[Hurricane Katrina]] or the [[2004 Indian Ocean earthquake]] are considered notable by these standards. On the other hand, a minor earthquake or storm with little or no devastation is not notable.
+

For example, [[Hurricane Katrina]] or the [[2004 Indian Ocean earthquake]] are notable by these standards. A minor earthquake or storm with little or no impact on human populations is probably not notable.
      +
A lasting effect may be difficult or impossible to determine shortly after the event occurs.
−

Consider delaying the nomination for a few days to avoid the deletion debate dealing with a moving target, and think about alternatives such as potential merge targets or ways to rework the article so that it conforms with policy, particularly for articles about people involved in events. Other alternatives to deletion while the story develops are [[WP:USERFY|userfying]] and moving the article into the [[WP:INCUBATE|Article Incubator]]. Moving a page to Wikinews is not possible as this would relicense it under the CC-BY license, which is incompatible with CC-BY-SA and GFDL — see [[Wikipedia:Wikinews]] — but the content could be reworked from the original sources for Wikinews with a [[Wikipedia:Soft redirect|soft redirect]] from Wikipedia.
        ⚫
Many events portrayed by the media as major on the day they occur quickly become only a footnote. For example, it was reported in January 2009 that [[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/Asa Seeley|a man was planning to travel to Washington to assassinate Barack Obama]]. It was reported several days later that he had no such plans and this event was shown to be nothing more than a [[West Baltimore (MARC station)#Site of arrest|routine arrest]].
−
===Anticipation===
  −
<!-- Please discuss before removing -->
  ⚫
{{shortcut|WP:ANTICIPATION}}
  −
Anticipation is the expectation that when an event breaks that it will beyond a reasonable doubt meet inclusion guidelines for news events, thereby resulting in the creation of an article on the event.
        ⚫
Articles about breaking news events —particularly biographies of participants— are often rapidly nominated for deletion. Consider delaying the nomination for a few days to avoid the deletion debate dealing with a moving target. There may be alternatives to deletion such as merging or reworking the article so that it conforms with policy, such as rewriting an article about a person known only for one event to be about the event. Other alternatives to deletion while the story develops are [[WP:USERFY|userfying]] or moving the article into the [[WP:INCUBATE|Article Incubator]].
⚫
Wikipedia has seen a lot of articles on events created in ''anticipation'' of their notability. For example, an article on the [[2009 Washington Metro train collision]] was created just 60 minutes after the actual crash occurred. At this time, a rescue operation was still in place, an investigation was yet to have begun, and the final death toll was yet to be known.
        +
===Wikinews===
−
While many such articles on breaking news may go unchallenged, in reality, [[WP:CRYSTAL|Wikipedia is not a crystal ball]]. When creating such articles, it is wise but not required to evaluate the circumstances and consider starting work on the event by adding information about it to the article on the most closely related subject, and when this outgrows the capacity for that article, to split it into a separate page.
    +
{{main|Wikipedia:Wikinews}}
  +
Editors are encouraged to write about breaking news events in [[Wikinews]] instead of in Wikipedia.
      +
Moving a page to Wikinews is not possible as this would re-license it under the CC-BY license, which is incompatible with CC-BY-SA and GFDL, but the content could be reworked from the original sources for Wikinews with a [[Wikipedia:Soft redirect|soft redirect]] from Wikipedia.
⚫
It is not uncommon for an event to be portrayed as major on the day it occurs, and then later fade into a footnote. For example, it was reported on the day of the event that the subject named in [[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/Asa Seeley|this AfD]] was catching a train to the White House to assassinate the president. It was determined several days later that he had no such plans, and this event became nothing more than a routine arrest.

Line 62: Line 62:      
Non-routine coverage may include important developments regarding politics, economics, crime, war, and disasters, as well as certain aspects of law, business, science, and technology.
 
Non-routine coverage may include important developments regarding politics, economics, crime, war, and disasters, as well as certain aspects of law, business, science, and technology.
−   −
===Routine long-term coverage===
  −
Certain types of events may receive some coverage over an extended period of time, even for several years. Nevertheless, they are still routine and are not notable.
  −   −
For example, in most urban areas, crime is a regular issue. In a typical homicide case that occurs in a major city, there is the crime itself, resulting in reports of a murder having occurred. There is an investigation, in which police are asking the public for leads. There is the identification of a suspect, where the public is told to look out for the suspect. There is the arrest, where it is reported that the suspect has been arrested. There is the bail review, along with other hearings. The results are sometimes reported. There is the prosecution, then the trial. The defendant is then convicted. Later, there is the sentencing, and the defendant, now a convict, is sentenced. ''Case closed''.
  −   −
This same routine takes place hundreds of times a year in some cities, tens of thousands of times a year worldwide. Such cases may be of prime importance to the people they immediately impact, but have no encyclopedic value.
       
===Reliability and bias===
 
===Reliability and bias===

An event affecting a local area and reported only by the media within the immediate region is generally not notable, and does not justify a separate article, regardless of the number of [[WP:RS|reliable sources]] that can be provided. An event that receives national or international coverage may reflect widespread interest and is more likely to be notable.
+
An event affecting a local area and reported only by the media within the immediate region is generally not notable as it is only of [[WP:LOCAL|local interest]]. Such coverage does not justify a separate article regardless of the number of [[WP:RS|reliable sources]] that can be provided. Coverage of an event nationally or internationally is generally required for inclusion, though it does ''not'' grant automatic notability to the event.
     
In the case where a television or radio channel has several regional outlets, such as [[Fox News]], one regional station counts as local coverage. Repeating this over multiple stations belonging to the same network that covers an entire country is considered to be a single instance of coverage with national or global scope.
 
In the case where a television or radio channel has several regional outlets, such as [[Fox News]], one regional station counts as local coverage. Repeating this over multiple stations belonging to the same network that covers an entire country is considered to be a single instance of coverage with national or global scope.
−   −
What defines an event as "local" is if it is covered ''only'' by media sources covering the point where it took place. For example, the [[September 11 attacks]] took place in [[New York City]], and the [[New York Times]] is one of the papers specializing in covering the exact geographic point of this event. Had this story only been covered in the New York Times and on New York's TV and radio news networks, this event would have remained a [[WP:LOCAL|local interest]]. But since this event was covered in the news outlets of virtually every other geographic location, it therefore is said to have gone beyond local.
  −   −
Having coverage expanding beyond the locality is generally a requirement for inclusion, though it does ''not'' grant automatic notability to the event.

Events are often considered to be notable if they act as a precedent or catalyst for something else. This may include effects on the views and behaviors of society and legislation. For example, the [[Murder of Adam Walsh]] ultimately led to the [[Adam Walsh Child Protection and Safety Act]], among other notable subjects. The murder of [[Matthew Shepard]] has led to reform of [[hate crime]] legislation at local, state and federal levels, such as the [[Matthew Shepard Act]].

==Criteria==
   
Many events receive coverage in the news and yet are not of historic or lasting importance. News organizations have criteria for content, i.e. [[news values]], that differ from the criteria used by Wikipedia. A violent crime, accidental death, or other [[media event]]s may be interesting enough to reporters and news editors to justify coverage, but this will not always translate into sufficient notability for a Wikipedia article.

+
Per [[WP:GNG|Wikipedia's general notability guideline]], <u>multiple sources are required</u>, not just multiple references from a single source. A series of news reports by a single newspaper or news channel would not be sufficient basis for an article.
    −
Similarly, where a single news wire story or press release has been used by several news publications, this should only be counted as a single source in all notability decisions. Likewise, when reporters base their information on other news coverage (for example, "[[Associated Press|AP]] reported that ..."), the coverage is only a single source. Such derivative reports are not independent and so cannot be used to verify each other. However, if multiple mainstream news outlets report on a single event separately and without reference to others, these constitute multiple sources.

Line 19: Line 19:      
===Depth of coverage===
 
===Depth of coverage===
−
Coverage must be significant and not in passing. In depth coverage that includes analysis and which puts events into context, such as is often found in books, feature length articles in major news magazines (like ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'', ''[[Newsweek]]'', and ''[[The Economist]]''), and TV news specialty shows (such as [[60 minutes]] or [[CNN Presents]]), is a much better indication of notability than is news coverage that merely narrates recent events such as do many daily newspaper, wire service, and nightly TV news stories. Such reporting with little thematic connection or contextual information,[http://www.questia.com/googleScholar.qst;jsessionid=KjpQbmrL6PGhG9rrVG2Gg1NWkb8PJQ8stDyWpNlfWvvP7vv2X7C1!1977393224!-1845046985?docId=5002028519] that lacks insight or critique,[http://books.google.co.uk/books?hl=en&lr=&id=JV0XQUF-o6gC&oi=fnd&pg=PA230&dq=%22Routine+news+coverage%22&ots=D24lsTZgV8&sig=7GIp4N5-wEMNSWgKYYFbDGn0prI#v=onepage&q=%22Routine%20news%20coverage%22&f=false][http://books.google.co.uk/books?hl=en&lr=&id=M7L1d_XjwsoC&oi=fnd&pg=PA61&dq=Routine#v=onepage&q=Routine&f=false] and that is written by 'beat reporters' rather than columnists[http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2585242/] is often considered to be routine reporting. Some editors consider narrative news reports to be [[WP:PRIMARY|primary]] rather than secondary sources.
+
The general guideline is that coverage must be significant and not in passing. In depth coverage that includes analysis and which puts events into context, such as is often found in books, feature length articles in major news magazines (like ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'', ''[[Newsweek]]'', and ''[[The Economist]]''), and TV news specialty shows (such as [[60 minutes]] or [[CNN Presents]]), is a much better indication of notability than is news coverage that merely narrates recent events such as do many daily newspaper, wire services, and nightly TV news stories. Such reporting with little thematic connection or contextual information,[http://www.questia.com/googleScholar.qst;jsessionid=KjpQbmrL6PGhG9rrVG2Gg1NWkb8PJQ8stDyWpNlfWvvP7vv2X7C1!1977393224!-1845046985?docId=5002028519] that lacks insight or critique,[http://books.google.co.uk/books?hl=en&lr=&id=JV0XQUF-o6gC&oi=fnd&pg=PA230&dq=%22Routine+news+coverage%22&ots=D24lsTZgV8&sig=7GIp4N5-wEMNSWgKYYFbDGn0prI#v=onepage&q=%22Routine%20news%20coverage%22&f=false][http://books.google.co.uk/books?hl=en&lr=&id=M7L1d_XjwsoC&oi=fnd&pg=PA61&dq=Routine#v=onepage&q=Routine&f=false] and that is written by 'beat reporters' rather than columnists[http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2585242/] is often considered to be routine reporting. Some editors consider narrative news reports to be [[WP:PRIMARY|primary]] rather than secondary sources.
     
Media sources sometimes report on events because of their similarity to another widely reported incident. Editors should not rely on such sources to afford notability to the new event, since the main purpose of such articles is to highlight the old event.

But since this event was covered in the news outlets of virtually every other geographic location, it therefore is said to have gone beyond local.

[[WP:NOTNEWS|Per Wikipedia policy]], routine news coverage of such things as announcements, sports, and tabloid journalism are not sufficient basis for an article. Planned coverage of pre-scheduled events,[http://english.peopledaily.com.cn/english/200102/08/eng20010208_61814.html][http://mcs.sagepub.com/cgi/content/abstract/20/3/471] especially when those involved in the event are also promoting it,[http://books.google.co.uk/books?hl=en&lr=&id=JV0XQUF-o6gC&oi=fnd&pg=PA200&dq=Routine#v=onepage&q=Routine&f=false] is considered to be routine. Routine events such as sports matches, film premieres, press conferences etc. may be better covered as part of another article, if at all. It has been suggested that the [[Wikipedia:Run-of-the-mill|run-of-the-mill]] events — common, everyday, ordinary items that do not stand out — are probably not notable.

Line 10: Line 10:  
Wikipedia is [[Wikipedia:What Wikipedia is not#Wikipedia is not a paper encyclopedia|not a paper encyclopedia]], which means that there is no practical limit to the number of topics we can cover or the total amount of content. However, it is also [[WP:NOT#IINFO|not an indiscriminate collection of information]] or a [[Wikipedia:NOT#NEWS|news service]]. Editors wishing to document a current news event can write for [[Wikinews]]. Not every incident that gains news coverage will have or should have a Wikipedia article. Reporting should be in sources that have a national or global scope, and a rule of thumb on whether an article should be written is whether the event is of lasting, historical significance, bearing in mind the question of [[Wikipedia:Recentism|recentism]].

===Inclusion and exclusion guidelines===
 
==Criteria==
 
==Criteria==
 
Many events receive coverage in the news and yet are not of historic or lasting importance. News organizations have criteria for content, i.e. [[news values]], that differ from the criteria used by Wikipedia. A violent crime, accidental death, or other [[media event]]s may be interesting enough to reporters and news editors to justify coverage, but this will not always translate into sufficient notability for a Wikipedia article.

Line 73: Line 73:      
Articles about breaking news events, particularly those about people involved, are often quickly nominated for deletion. Consider delaying the nomination for a few days to avoid the deletion debate dealing with a moving target, and think about alternatives such as potential merge targets or ways to rework the article so that it conforms with policy, particularly for articles about people involved in events. Other alternatives to deletion while the story develops are [[WP:USERFY|userfying]] and moving the article into the [[WP:INCUBATE|Article Incubator]]. Moving a page to Wikinews is not possible as this would relicense it under the CC-BY license, which is incompatible with CC-BY-SA and GFDL — see [[Wikipedia:Wikinews]] — but the content could be reworked from the original sources for Wikinews with a [[Wikipedia:Soft redirect|soft redirect]] from Wikipedia.

===Depth===
+
===Depth of coverage===
 
Coverage must be significant and not in passing. In depth coverage that includes analysis and which puts events into context, such as is often found in books, feature length articles in major news magazines (like ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'', ''[[Newsweek]]'', and ''[[The Economist]]''), and TV news specialty shows (such as [[60 minutes]] or [[CNN Presents]]), is a much better indication of notability than is news coverage that merely narrates recent events such as do many daily newspaper, wire service, and nightly TV news stories. Such reporting with little thematic connection or contextual information,[http://www.questia.com/googleScholar.qst;jsessionid=KjpQbmrL6PGhG9rrVG2Gg1NWkb8PJQ8stDyWpNlfWvvP7vv2X7C1!1977393224!-1845046985?docId=5002028519] that lacks insight or critique,[http://books.google.co.uk/books?hl=en&lr=&id=JV0XQUF-o6gC&oi=fnd&pg=PA230&dq=%22Routine+news+coverage%22&ots=D24lsTZgV8&sig=7GIp4N5-wEMNSWgKYYFbDGn0prI#v=onepage&q=%22Routine%20news%20coverage%22&f=false][http://books.google.co.uk/books?hl=en&lr=&id=M7L1d_XjwsoC&oi=fnd&pg=PA61&dq=Routine#v=onepage&q=Routine&f=false] and that is written by 'beat reporters' rather than columnists[http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2585242/] is often considered to be routine reporting. Some editors consider narrative news reports to be [[WP:PRIMARY|primary]] rather than secondary sources.

===Persistence===
+
===Persistence of coverage===
 
The persistence or duration of coverage is a strong indicator of whether an event has passing or lasting significance. Although [[WP:NTEMP|notability is not temporary]], meaning that coverage does not need to be ongoing for notability to be established, a burst or spike of news reports does not automatically make an incident notable. Editors [[WP:CRYSTAL|should not speculate]] on whether an event will receive further coverage. Events that are only covered in sources published during or immediately after an event, without further analysis or discussion, are likely not suitable for an encyclopedia article.

Wedding announcements, obituaries, sports scores, crime logs, and other items that tend to get an exemption from newsworthiness discussions should be considered routine. Routine events such as sports matches, film premieres, press conferences etc. may be better covered as part of another article, if at all. It has been suggested that the [[Wikipedia:Run-of-the-mill|run-of-the-mill]] events — common, everyday, ordinary items that do not stand out — are probably not notable.

====Weaknesses in news reporting====
+
===Reliability and bias===
 
[[Tabloid_journalism#To_refer_to_sensationalist_journalistic_practices|Tabloid]] or [[yellow journalism]] is usually considered a poor basis for an encyclopedia article, due to the lack of fact checking inherent in [[Sensationalism|sensationalist]] and [[scandal mongering]] news reporting. Even in respected media, a [[24-hour news cycle]] and other pressures inherent in the journalism industry can lead to [[infotainment]] and [[churnalism]] without proper fact checking, and they may engage in frivolous "[[silly season]]" reporting. Some editors take into account perceived [[media bias]], such as [[Missing white woman syndrome]], when assessing notability.

===Impact===
  ⚫
Events are often considered to be notable if they act as a precedent or catalyst for something else. An example of this is the murder of [[Matthew Shepard]], which led to reform of [[hate crime]] legislation at local, state and [[Matthew Shepard Act|federal]] levels of the United States government. Events that permanently affect a region will be notable, such as [[Hurricane Katrina]] or the [[2004 Indian Ocean earthquake]].

Coverage must be significant and not in passing. In depth coverage that includes analysis and which puts events into context, such as is often found in books, feature length articles in major news magazines (like ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'', ''[[Newsweek]]'', and ''[[The Economist]]''), and TV news specialty shows (such as [[60 minutes]] or [[CNN Presents]]), is a much better indication of notability than is news coverage that merely narrates recent events such as do many daily newspaper, wire service, and nightly TV news stories. Such reporting with little thematic connection or contextual information,[http://www.questia.com/googleScholar.qst;jsessionid=KjpQbmrL6PGhG9rrVG2Gg1NWkb8PJQ8stDyWpNlfWvvP7vv2X7C1!1977393224!-1845046985?docId=5002028519] that lacks insight or critique,[http://books.google.co.uk/books?hl=en&lr=&id=JV0XQUF-o6gC&oi=fnd&pg=PA230&dq=%22Routine+news+coverage%22&ots=D24lsTZgV8&sig=7GIp4N5-wEMNSWgKYYFbDGn0prI#v=onepage&q=%22Routine%20news%20coverage%22&f=false][http://books.google.co.uk/books?hl=en&lr=&id=M7L1d_XjwsoC&oi=fnd&pg=PA61&dq=Routine#v=onepage&q=Routine&f=false] and that is written by 'beat reporters' rather than columnists[http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2585242/] is often considered to be routine reporting. Some editors consider narrative news reports to be [[WP:PRIMARY|primary]] rather than secondary sources.

===Breadth and scope===
+
===Geographical scope===
  +
{{Seealso|Wikipedia:Notability (local interests)}}
−
An event affecting a local area and reported only by the media within the immediate region is generally not notable, and does not justify a separate article, regardless of the number of [[WP:RS|reliable sources]] that can be provided. See the proposal [[Wikipedia:Notability (local interests)]]. An event that receives national or international coverage may reflect widespread interest and is more likely to be notable. In the case where a television or radio channel has several regional outlets, such as [[Fox News]], one regional station counts as local coverage. Repeating this over multiple stations belonging to the same network that covers an entire country is considered to be a single instance of coverage with national or global scope.

===Diversity of sources===
 
Multiple sources are required, not just multiple references from a single or small number of sources. A series of news reports by a single newspaper or news channel would not be sufficient basis for an article.
 
Multiple sources are required, not just multiple references from a single or small number of sources. A series of news reports by a single newspaper or news channel would not be sufficient basis for an article.
     
Similarly, where a single news wire story or press release has been used by several news publications, this should only be counted as a single source in all notability decisions. Likewise, when reporters base their information on other news coverage (for example, "[[Associated Press|AP]] reported that ..."), the coverage is only a single source. Such derivative reports are not independent and so cannot be used to verify each other. However, if multiple mainstream news outlets report on a single event separately and without reference to others, these constitute multiple sources.

Such derivative reports are not independent and so cannot be used to verify each other. However, if multiple mainstream news outlets report on a single event separately and without reference to others, these constitute multiple sources.

Editors should evaluate various aspects of the sources prior to creating an article with that information: the depth, persistence, breadth, scope, and content of the coverage.
−   −
===Inclusion and exclusion guidelines===
  −
The following criteria may be used for inclusion:
  −   −
====Geography====
  −
An event is considered ''local'' if it is covered ''only'' in the paper(s) of the point where it took place. For example, the [[September 11 attacks]] took place in [[New York City]], and the [[New York Times]] is one of the papers specializing in covering the exact geographic point of this event. Had this story only been covered in the New York Times and on New York's TV and radio news networks, this event would have remained a [[WP:LOCAL|local interest]]. But this event was covered in the news outlets of virtually every other geographic location, thereby making the event go beyond local.
  −   −
While coverage expanding beyond the locality is usually a requirement for inclusion, this does ''not'' grant automatic notability to the event.
  −   −
====Length of coverage====
  −
Some events receive coverage only in the day immediately following their occurrence. These events per [[WP:ONEEVENT]] guidelines are <u>not</u> notable for standalone articles. They are, however, in some cases, be worthy of inclusion in another article when they have an impact on the status of the subject of that article.
  −   −
Other events may receive continued coverage for a somewhat or substantially extended period of time. While coverage may and often does end, these may be worthy of a standalone article ''if'' it can be documented from sources that they have a lasting impact on society.
  −

Line 82: Line 69:      
Articles about breaking news events, particularly those about people involved, are often quickly nominated for deletion. Consider delaying the nomination for a few days to avoid the deletion debate dealing with a moving target, and think about alternatives such as potential merge targets or ways to rework the article so that it conforms with policy, particularly for articles about people involved in events. Other alternatives to deletion while the story develops are [[WP:USERFY|userfying]] and moving the article into the [[WP:INCUBATE|Article Incubator]]. Moving a page to Wikinews is not possible as this would relicense it under the CC-BY license, which is incompatible with CC-BY-SA and GFDL, but the content could be reworked from the original sources for Wikinews with a [[Wikipedia:Soft redirect|soft redirect]] from Wikipedia.
 
Articles about breaking news events, particularly those about people involved, are often quickly nominated for deletion. Consider delaying the nomination for a few days to avoid the deletion debate dealing with a moving target, and think about alternatives such as potential merge targets or ways to rework the article so that it conforms with policy, particularly for articles about people involved in events. Other alternatives to deletion while the story develops are [[WP:USERFY|userfying]] and moving the article into the [[WP:INCUBATE|Article Incubator]]. Moving a page to Wikinews is not possible as this would relicense it under the CC-BY license, which is incompatible with CC-BY-SA and GFDL, but the content could be reworked from the original sources for Wikinews with a [[Wikipedia:Soft redirect|soft redirect]] from Wikipedia.
−   −
===Anticipation===
  −
{{shortcut|WP:ANTICIPATION}}
  −
Anticipation is the belief when an event breaks that it will beyond a reasonable doubt meet inclusion guidelines for news events, thereby resulting in the creation of an article on the event.
  −   −
Wikipedia has seen a lot of articles on events created in ''anticipation'' of their notability. For example, an article on the [[2009 Washington Metro train collision]] was created just 60 minutes after the actual crash occurred. At this time, a rescue operation was still in place, an investigation was yet to have begun, and the final death toll was yet to be known.
  −   −
While many such articles on breaking news may go unchallenged, in reality, [[WP:CRYSTAL|Wikipedia is not a crystal ball]]. When creating such articles, it is wise to evaluate the circumstances and consider starting work on the event by adding information about it to the article on the most closely related subject, and when this outgrows the capacity for that article, to split it into a separate page.

Planned coverage of pre-scheduled events,[http://english.peopledaily.com.cn/english/200102/08/eng20010208_61814.html][http://mcs.sagepub.com/cgi/content/abstract/20/3/471] especially when those involved in the event are also promoting it,[http://books.google.co.uk/books?hl=en&lr=&id=JV0XQUF-o6gC&oi=fnd&pg=PA200&dq=Routine#v=onepage&q=Routine&f=false] is considered to be routine. Wedding announcements, obituaries, sports scores, crime logs, and other items that tend to get an exemption from newsworthiness discussions should be considered routine. Routine events such as sports matches, film premieres, press conferences etc. may be better covered as part of another article, if at all. It has been suggested that the [[Wikipedia:Run-of-the-mill|run-of-the-mill]] events — common, everyday, ordinary items that do not stand out — are probably not notable.

Line 28: Line 28:  
An event affecting a local area and reported only by the media within the immediate region is generally not notable, and does not justify a separate article, regardless of the number of [[WP:RS|reliable sources]] that can be provided. An event that receives national or international coverage may reflect widespread interest and is more likely to be notable. In the case where a television or radio channel has several regional outlets, such as [[Fox News]], one regional station counts as local coverage. Repeating this over multiple stations belonging to the same network that covers an entire country is considered to be a single instance of coverage with national or global scope.

An event that receives national or international coverage may reflect widespread interest and is more likely to be notable. In the case where a television or radio channel has several regional outlets, such as [[Fox News]], one regional station counts as local coverage. Repeating this over multiple stations belonging to the same network that covers an entire country is considered to be a single instance of coverage with national or global scope.
    −
Multiple sources are required, not just multiple references from a single or small number of sources. It would be insufficient to base an article on a series of news reports by a single newspaper or news channel.
+
Multiple sources are required, not just multiple references from a single or small number of sources. A series of news reports by a single newspaper or news channel would not be sufficient basis for an article.
     
Similarly, where a single news wire story or press release has been used by several news publications, this should only be counted as a single source in all notability decisions. Likewise, when reporters base their information on other news coverage (for example, "[[Associated Press|AP]] reported that ..."), the coverage is only a single source. Such derivative reports are not independent and so cannot be used to verify each other. However, if multiple mainstream news outlets report on a single event separately and without reference to others, these constitute multiple sources.

Line 21: Line 21:      
===Persistence===
 
===Persistence===
  ⚫
The persistence of coverage is a strong indicator of whether an event has passing or lasting significance. Although [[WP:NTEMP|notability is not temporary]], meaning that coverage does not need to be ongoing for notability to be established, a burst or spike of news reports does not automatically make an incident notable. Editors [[WP:CRYSTAL|should not speculate]] on whether an event will receive further coverage. Events that are only covered in sources published during or immediately after an event, without further analysis or discussion, are likely not suitable for an encyclopedia article.
−
The persistence of coverage is a strong indicator of whether an event has passing or lasting significance.
        ⚫
Events are often considered to be notable if they act as a precedent or catalyst for something else. An example of this is the murder of [[Matthew Shepard]], which led to reform of [[hate crime]] legislation at local, state and [[Matthew Shepard Act|federal]] levels of the United States government. Events that permanently affect a region will be notable, such as [[Hurricane Katrina]] or the [[2004 Indian Ocean earthquake]]. If an event is cited as a [[case study]] in multiple sources after the initial coverage has died down, this may be an indication of lasting significance.

Line 12: Line 12:  
==Criteria==
 
==Criteria==
 
Many events receive coverage in the news and yet are not of historic or lasting importance. News organizations have criteria for content, i.e. [[news values]], that differ from the criteria used by Wikipedia. A violent crime, accidental death, or other [[media event]]s may be interesting enough to reporters and news editors to justify coverage, but this will not always translate into sufficient notability for a Wikipedia article.
 
Many events receive coverage in the news and yet are not of historic or lasting importance. News organizations have criteria for content, i.e. [[news values]], that differ from the criteria used by Wikipedia. A violent crime, accidental death, or other [[media event]]s may be interesting enough to reporters and news editors to justify coverage, but this will not always translate into sufficient notability for a Wikipedia article.
  +   +
Policies and guidelines that editors often use as a guide on whether to have an article about a single event include [[WP:NOT#NEWS]], [[WP:NTEMP]], [[WP:BIO1E]], [[WP:BLP1E]] and [[WP:N/CA]]. This guideline clarifies the application of these rules to articles about events.
     
Editors should evaluate various aspects of the sources prior to creating an article with that information: the depth, persistence, breadth, scope, and content of the coverage.
 
Editors should evaluate various aspects of the sources prior to creating an article with that information: the depth, persistence, breadth, scope, and content of the coverage.

Line 80: Line 80:  
==Criminal acts==
 
==Criminal acts==
 
{{mainarticle|Wikipedia:Notability (criminal acts)}}
 
{{mainarticle|Wikipedia:Notability (criminal acts)}}
−
A "criminal act" includes a matter in which a crime has been established, or a matter has been deemed a likely crime by the relevant law enforcement agency or judicial authority. For example, the disappearance of a person would fall under this guideline if law enforcement agencies deemed it likely to have been caused by criminal conduct, regardless of whether a perpetrator is identified or charged. If a matter is deemed notable, and to be a likely crime, the article should remain even if it is subsequently found that no crime occurred (e.g., the [[Runaway bride case]]) since that would not make the matter less notable. Intense media coverage can confer notability on a high-profile criminal act, provided such coverage meets Wikipedia's policies and guidelines on [[WP:RS|reliable sources]].
+
There is a specific notability guideline for criminal acts. A "criminal act" includes a matter in which a crime has been established, or a matter has been deemed a likely crime by the relevant law enforcement agency or judicial authority. For example, the disappearance of a person would fall under this guideline if law enforcement agencies deemed it likely to have been caused by criminal conduct, regardless of whether a perpetrator is identified or charged. If a matter is deemed notable, and to be a likely crime, the article should remain even if it is subsequently found that no crime occurred (e.g., the [[Runaway bride case]]) since that would not make the matter less notable. Intense media coverage can confer notability on a high-profile criminal act, provided such coverage meets Wikipedia's policies and guidelines on [[WP:RS|reliable sources]].

Line 70: Line 70:  
Articles about breaking news events, particularly those about people involved, are often quickly nominated for deletion. Consider delaying the nomination for a few days to avoid the deletion debate dealing with a moving target, and think about alternatives such as potential merge targets or ways to rework the article so that it conforms with policy, particularly for articles about people involved in events. Other alternatives to deletion while the story develops are [[WP:USERFY|userfying]] and moving the article into the [[WP:INCUBATE|Article Incubator]]. Moving a page to Wikinews is not possible as this would relicense it under the CC-BY license, which is incompatible with CC-BY-SA and GFDL, but the content could be reworked from the original sources for Wikinews with a [[Wikipedia:Soft redirect|soft redirect]] from Wikipedia.

==People involved in events==
   
Someone known only for one event should generally not have an article written about them, but if the event they were part of is notable an article should be written about the event instead. Biographical information about participants should be limited to that which can be linked to the event; material that establishes the notablility of the event, or which is reasonably required to explain some aspect of the event.

==Alternatives to deletion==
 
If the notability of an event is in question but it is primarily associated with a particular person, company or organization, or can be covered as part of a wider topic, it may preferable to describe the event within a preexisting article, by [[WP:MERGE|merging]] content. Care should be taken to not not give the event [[WP:UNDUE|undue weight]] or violate our policy on [[WP:BLP|biographies of living persons]].

===Breadth and scope===
−
An event affecting a local area and reported only by the media within the immediate region is generally not notable, and does not justify a separate article, regardless of the number of [[WP:RS|reliable sources]] that can be provided. An event that receives national or international coverage may reflect widespread interest and is more likely to be notable.
+
An event affecting a local area and reported only by the media within the immediate region is generally not notable, and does not justify a separate article, regardless of the number of [[WP:RS|reliable sources]] that can be provided. An event that receives national or international coverage may reflect widespread interest and is more likely to be notable. In the case where a television or radio channel has several regional outlets, such as [[Fox News]], one regional station counts as local coverage. Repeating this over multiple stations belonging to the same network that covers an entire country is considered to be a single instance of coverage with national or global scope.
  +   +
Multiple sources are required, not just multiple references from a single or small number of sources. It would be insufficient to base an article on a series of news reports by a single newspaper or news channel.
  +   +
Similarly, where a single news wire story or press release has been used by several news publications, this should only be counted as a single source in all notability decisions. Likewise, when reporters base their information on other news coverage (for example, "[[Associated Press|AP]] reported that ..."), the coverage is only a single source. Such derivative reports are not independent and so cannot be used to verify each other. However, if multiple mainstream news outlets report on a single event separately and without reference to others, these constitute multiple sources.
  +   +
Finally, media sources sometimes report on events because of their similarity to another widely reported incident. Editors should not rely on such sources to afford notability to the new event, since the main purpose of such articles is to highlight the old event.
