====Weaknesses in news reporting====
 
[[Tabloid_journalism#To_refer_to_sensationalist_journalistic_practices|Tabloid]] or [[yellow journalism]] is usually considered a poor basis for an encyclopedia article, due to the lack of fact checking inherent in [[Sensationalism|sensationalist]] and [[scandal mongering]] news reporting. Even in respected media, a [[24-hour news cycle]] and other pressures inherent in the journalism industry can lead to [[infotainment]] and [[churnalism]] without proper fact checking, and they may engage in frivolous "[[silly season]]" reporting. Some editors take into account perceived [[media bias]], such as [[Missing white woman syndrome]], when assessing notability.

Consider delaying the nomination for a few days to avoid the deletion debate dealing with a moving target, and think about alternatives such as potential merge targets or ways to rework the article so that it conforms with policy, particularly for articles about people involved in events. Line 57: Line 57:  
{{mainarticle|Wikipedia:Notability (criminal acts)}}
 
{{mainarticle|Wikipedia:Notability (criminal acts)}}
 
A "criminal act" includes a matter in which a crime has been established, or a matter has been deemed a likely crime by the relevant law enforcement agency or judicial authority. For example, the disappearance of a person would fall under this guideline if law enforcement agencies deemed it likely to have been caused by criminal conduct, regardless of whether a perpetrator is identified or charged. If a matter is deemed notable, and to be a likely crime, the article should remain even if it is subsequently found that no crime occurred (e.g., the [[Runaway bride case]]) since that would not make the matter less notable. Intense media coverage can confer notability on a high-profile criminal act, provided such coverage meets Wikipedia's policies and guidelines on [[WP:RS|reliable sources]].

For example, the disappearance of a person would fall under this guideline if law enforcement agencies deemed it likely to have been caused by criminal conduct, regardless of whether a perpetrator is identified or charged. If a matter is deemed notable, and to be a likely crime, the article should remain even if it is subsequently found that no crime occurred (e.g., the [[Runaway bride case]]) since that would not make the matter less notable. There is a category, [[:Category:Events]], which may be a guide on the types of articles about events considered acceptable by the community.
      +
==Routine news coverage==
⚫
==Passing vs. lasting significance==
    +
Per Wikipedia policy, routine news coverage of such things as announcements, sports, and tabloid journalism are not sufficient basis for an article. Wedding announcements, obituaries, sports scores, crime logs, and other things that tend to get an exemption from newsworthiness discussions should be considered routine. Routine events such as sports matches, film premieres, press conferences etc. may be better covered as part of another article, if at all.
  +   +
==Scope of coverage==
  ⚫
An event affecting a local area and reported only by the media within the immediate region is generally not notable, and does not justify a separate article, regardless of the number of [[WP:RS|reliable sources]] that can be provided. An event that receives national or international coverage is more likely to be notable.
  +   ⚫
==Persistence of coverage: passing vs. lasting significance==
 
Although [[WP:NTEMP|notability is not temporary]], meaning that coverage does not need to be ongoing for notability to be established, a burst or spike of news reports does not automatically make an incident notable. Editors [[WP:CRYSTAL|should not speculate]] on whether an event will receive further coverage. Coverage must be significant and not in passing, and editors should note whether news reports are all mostly based on a single source such as an [[Associated Press]] or [[Reuters]] newswire story.

Line 44: Line 44:  
==Criminal acts==
 
==Criminal acts==
 
{{mainarticle|Wikipedia:Notability (criminal acts)}}

−
{{mergefrom|Wikipedia:Notability (criminal acts)| discuss=Wikipedia talk:Notability (news events)#Should Wikipedia:Notability (criminal acts) be merged into Wikipedia:Notability (news events)?| date=October 2009}}
   
A "criminal act" includes a matter in which a crime has been established, or a matter has been deemed a likely crime by the relevant law enforcement agency or judicial authority. For example, the disappearance of a person would fall under this guideline if law enforcement agencies deemed it likely to have been caused by criminal conduct, regardless of whether a perpetrator is identified or charged. If a matter is deemed notable, and to be a likely crime, the article should remain even if it is subsequently found that no crime occurred (e.g., the [[Runaway bride case]]) since that would not make the matter less notable. Intense media coverage can confer notability on a high-profile criminal act, provided such coverage meets Wikipedia's policies and guidelines on [[WP:RS|reliable sources]].

Line 8: Line 8:      
Wikipedia is [[Wikipedia:What Wikipedia is not#Wikipedia is not a paper encyclopedia|not a paper encyclopedia]], which means that there is no practical limit to the number of topics we can cover or the total amount of content. However, it is also [[WP:NOT#IINFO|not an indiscriminate collection of information]] or a [[Wikipedia:NOT#NEWS|news service]]. Editors wishing to document a current news event can write for [[Wikinews]]. Not every incident that gains news coverage will have or should have a Wikipedia article. Reporting should be in sources that have a national or global scope, and a rule of thumb on whether an article should be written is whether the event is of lasting, historical significance, bearing in mind the question of [[Wikipedia:Recentism|recentism]].

It may be wise to delay writing an article about a breaking news event until the significance of the event is clearer. It may be wise to delay writing an article about a breaking news event until the significance of the event is clearer. Consider starting a section about the event in another article, which can later be spun out into its own article if the coverage warrants it, or writing about the event in [[Wikinews]].
    −
Articles about breaking news events, particularly those about people involved, are often quickly nominated for deletion. Consider delaying the nomination for a few days to avoid the deletion debate dealing with a moving target, and think about potential merge targets or ways to rework the article. Other alternatives to deletion while the story develops are [[WP:USERFY|userfying]] and the [[WP:INCUBATE|Article Incubator]]. Moving a page to Wikinews is not possible as this would relicense it under the CC-BY license, which is incompatible with CC-BY-SA and GFDL.

Whether Wikipedia should have articles detailing particular [[news]] events or incidents is a perennial and contentious question. Generally, a topic is presumed to be [[WP:NOTABILITY|notable]] and thus worthy of inclusion within Wikipedia if it has received significant coverage in multiple, independent [[WP:RS|reliable sources]]. This is the [[WP:GNG|general notability guideline]].
 
Whether Wikipedia should have articles detailing particular [[news]] events or incidents is a perennial and contentious question. Generally, a topic is presumed to be [[WP:NOTABILITY|notable]] and thus worthy of inclusion within Wikipedia if it has received significant coverage in multiple, independent [[WP:RS|reliable sources]]. This is the [[WP:GNG|general notability guideline]].
    −
However, it is a policy that [[Wikipedia:NOT#NEWS|Wikipedia is not a news service]]. Editors wishing to document a current news event can write for [[Wikinews]]. Not every incident that gains news coverage will have or should have a Wikipedia article. Reporting should be in sources that have a national or global scope, and a rule of thumb on whether an article should be written is whether the event is of lasting, historical significance, bearing in mind the question of [[Wikipedia:Recentism|recentism]].
+

Editors [[WP:CRYSTAL|should not speculate]] on whether an event will receive further coverage.       +
Many things are in the news and are reported by numerous reliable and verifiable sources that are independent of the subject, yet are not of historic or lasting importance. News organizations have different criteria for their content than the criteria used by encyclopedias. A violent crime, sensationalized event or accidental death may be notable enough to reporters and news editors to justify coverage in the news, but not in a Wikipedia article.
⚫
Events are often considered to be notable if they act as a precedent or catalyst for something else. An example of this is the murder of [[Matthew Shepard]], which led to reform of [[hate crime]] legislation at local, state and [[Matthew Shepard Act|federal]] levels of the United States government. Events that permanently affect a region will be notable, such as [[Hurricane Katrina]] or the [[2004 Indian Ocean earthquake]].

A "Criminal act" includes a matter in which a crime has been established, or a matter has been deemed a likely crime by the relevant law enforcement agency or judicial authority. For example, the disappearance of a person would fall under this guideline if law enforcement agencies deemed it likely to have been caused by criminal conduct, regardless of whether a perpetrator is identified or charged. If a matter is deemed notable, and to be a likely crime, the article should remain even if it is subsequently found that no crime occurred (e.g., the [[Runaway bride case]]) since that would not make the matter less notable. Intense media coverage can confer notability on a high-profile criminal act, provided such coverage meets Wikipedia's policies and guidelines on [[WP:RS|reliable sources]].

Whether Wikipedia should have articles detailing particular [[news]] events or incidents is a perennial and contentious question. Generally, a topic is presumed to be [[WP:NOTABILITY|notable]] and thus worthy of inclusion within Wikipedia if it has received significant coverage in multiple, independent [[WP:RS|reliable sources]]. This is the [[WP:GNG|general notability guideline]].
−
Generally, an item is notable if it has coverage in multiple sources independent of the topic itself. With news, however, determining notability can be a little more tricky. News articles by definition are [[WP:RS|reliable sources]]. All agree that major, earth-shattering events like the [[September 11 attacks]] or [[Hurricane Katrina]] are notable. At the same time, all agree that not every crime or fire in every city and town reported on three of its local news stations and in the local paper are notable. As for events whose level of importance is somewhere in between, drawing the line is not always so easy.
        +
However, it is a policy that [[Wikipedia:NOT#NEWS|Wikipedia is not a news service]]. Editors wishing to document a current news event can write for [[Wikinews]]. Not every incident that gains news coverage will have or should have a Wikipedia article. Reporting should be in sources that have a national or global scope, and a rule of thumb on whether an article should be written is whether the event is of lasting, historical significance, bearing in mind the question on [[Wikipedia:Recentism|recentism]].
⚫

===Breakthroughs===

−

        +
Not every natural disaster is notable, but those that permanently affect a region or change laws or government policy such as [[Hurricane Katrina]], the [[2004 Indian Ocean earthquake|2004 Boxing Day Tsunami]] or the [[2007 United Kingdom floods]].
−
===Product recalls===
  −
Product recalls are generally not notable. An unusually large recall that has a significant impact (such as the [[Peanut Corporation of America#2008-2009 salmonella outbreak|2008-2009 salmonella outbreak in peanut products]]) may be described in the article about the product (if one exists) or the manufacturer. If no article on the product or its manufacturer exists, it is not likely to be notable.
        +
If an event is cited as a [[case study]] in multiple sources that after the initial coverage has died down, this may be an indication of lasting significance.
−
==Events as an example==
  −
Many books and articles use specific people or events as a segue to a discussion of a larger issue. ==Individual stories==
  −
Many stories about the lives of events within the lives of one or a few individuals are told within newspaper columns, magazines, in published books, or on TV news broadcasts or programs. These stories, which include many cover stories, are told not to show the individual's fame but rather to highlight an example of a circumstance or situation that affects many other people. These stories are not written to show the individual's fame, but rather to highlight an example of a circumstance or situation that affects many other people. Such stories do not bring notability to the particular event or any of the people within it. ===Amusement stories===
  −
"Amusement" stories that appear on in type of news (local, national, or international) are not notable. An ''amusement'' story is one that is told by a media outlet to draw attention to itself or to be "catchy," but that has little or no impact on the world or on any significant group in the population.
  −   −
Some examples of amusement stories may be a car crashing into someone's house, or the sighting of an animal in an unsual place.

===Deaths===

Deaths attributed to accidents, natural causes, homicide or suicide are generally not considered notable, even if the cause of death is unusual. An example of this is the murder of [[Matthew Shepard]], which led to reform of [[hate crime]] legislation at local, state and federal levels of the United States government.

Generally, an item is notable if it has coverage in multiple sources independent of the topic itself. With news, however, determining notability can be a little more tricky. News articles by definition are [[WP:RS|reliable sources]]. All agree that major, earth-shattering events like the [[September 11 attacks]] or [[Hurricane Katrina]] are notable. At the same time, all agree that not every crime or fire in every city and town reported on three of its local news stations and in the local paper are notable. As for events whose level of importance is somewhere in between, drawing the line is not always so easy.
